concept.title: Swap space
concept.shortdesc: On Linux, swappiness indicates how frequently the system uses the swap space based on its RAM usage.

conbody.p: The swappiness range is from 0 to 100 where, by default, most Linux platforms have swappiness set to 60.

For optimal Couchbase Server performance and operation, set the OS swappiness to 0 (zero) or at most 1. T his tells the kernel to swap as little as possible to disk and favor RAM. The idea behind this is Couchbase is optimized with its managed cache to use RAM. It is capable of managing what should be in RAM and what should not be. By allowing the OS to control what memory pages are in RAM, you lower Couchbaseâ€™s effectiveness.
So we suggest the 0-1 setting for swappiness to make sure that Couchbase controls the RAM utilization and is not thwarted by the Operating System.

ol.li: Execute cat /proc/sys/vm/swappiness on each node to determine the current swap usage configuration.
Execute sudo sysctl vm.swappiness=0 to change the swap configuration immediately.

To ensure that this setting persists through the server restarts:
Using sudo or root user privileges, edit the kernel parameters configuration file /etc/sysctl.conf so that the change is always in effect.
Append vm.swappiness = 0 to the file.
Reboot your system.

conbody.note: If you are making a golden master OS image or use a configuration automation system, do not forget to make this permanent change there too.
On Windows, there is no recommended swap space optimization.
